debate.para: The following answers to questions upon notice were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister repre senting the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: How many (a) general practitioners and (b) specialists were there in each State and Territory in the last year for which figures are available.
What was the (a) number and (b) percentage of (i) general practitioners and (ii) specialists who were registered in the pensioner medical scheme.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

item.para: (a) Precise figures as to the number of general practitioners in private practice in each State and Territory are not available in my Department. However, one recent estimate puts the total number for the Commonwealth at 7,376.

item.label: (b)

item.para: In relation to the States Grunts (Deserted Wives) Act, what sum was spent by (a) the Commonwealth and (b) each State (i) for each category of applicant and (ii) in total in each yearsince the Act came into effect.
How many applicants have there been in (a) the Commonwealth and (b) each State in (i) each category and (ii) total in each of the same years.
Can he provide details of any means test applied by each of the States in respect of each category of applicant who may benefit under the Act.

What would have been the cost to the Commonwealth in 1970-71 in respect of each category of applicant in (a) each State and (b) total if the Commonwealth had assumed full financial responsibility for providing benefits under the Act and the means test applied was the same as that currently applied for widows' pensions.
What would be the estimated cost in 1971-72 based on the assumption in part (4).

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: All States provide assistance to various categories of women with children and subsequently claim reimbursement of proportionate amounts from the Commonwealth under the provisions of the States Grants (Deserted Wives) Act. It has been the practice to minimise the administrative costs of the States by keeping claim procedures as simple as possible. As a consequence it is not possible to provide details of expenditure in terms of each category of applicant. Commonwealth expenditure in the years concerned is set out in the following table and after Commonwealth reimbursements are deducted State expenditure is approximately equal to the amountspaid by the Commonwealth. However, it should be noted that the States lodge claims quarterly in arrears and at 30th June 1971, the June quarter claims had not been received from the States.

As explained at the time this programme was introduced (see Hansard of 2 May 1968, page 1061) assistance extends beyond cash payments and includes food and clothing and the States would continue to have regard to the individual needs of each case.
Approximately $8m.
On the basis of State forecasts of 1971-72 State expenditure the cost would be of the order of $12m.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice:

item.para: Will he initiate action to encourage private forestry as a means of rural reconstruction:

Will he examine the New South Wales Forestry Commission practice of developing a plantation by paying the entire development costs, meeting the interest for the 13 years during which no return is received and recognising that the complete outlay plus accumulated interest will not be recouped until the final cut 45 years from commencement.

Would an application of similar principles to the private farmer cost no more than the present system and assist in establishing much needed pine plantations while giving new opportunities sorely needed by farmers at this time.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows. The information in respect of parts (2) and (3) has been provided by the Minister for National Development:

item.para: The Commonwealth has undertaken to make available to the States $100m for the Rural Reconstruction Scheme and $25m for the Marginal Dairy

answer.para: Farms Reconstruction Scheme. The States may use the moneys provided for the purposes set out in the Marginal Dairy Farms Reconstruction Act and States Grant (Rural Reconstruction) Act. There is no specific provision for the moneys to be used for the encouragement of private forestry. I have no doubt that the State authorities administering these schemes would give favourable consideration to proposals for private afforestation providing it were regarded as a profitable form of land use by the State authority and the applicant could meet the eligibility conditions laid down in the Agreements with the States.

item.para: It is assumed that the honourable member is referring to plantings undertaken by the N.S.W. Forestry Commission on its own behalf. The appropriate Commonwealth Departments are quite familiar with these operations and no further examination would appear to be necessary.

There are significant savings in costs to be achieved by planting and managing forests in large units in excess of 30,000 acres, thus it is likely that dispersed plantings by farmers would cost more than large scale planting by Governments. Nevertheless means of assisting private landowners to establish plantations is under review by the Australian Forestry Council and the Department of National Development
